qas.question: Which view of evolution emphasizing large changes in organisms' phenotypes does Popper oppose to his own?
Which aspect of organisms changes most radically in the process of evolution Popper envisions?
How does Popper describe the "monsters" that evolve in his view of evolutionary processes?
What kind of Darwinism does Popper subscribe to in contrast to the naturalistic kind?

plausible_answers.text: small but quick changes of the phenotype

qas.question: What happens after behavior changes only a little?

plausible_answers.text: make the organism fitter to its changed goals

qas.question: What do large and slow changes to the phenotype do?

plausible_answers.text: the eating habits of the giraffe

qas.question: What changed after the giraffe evolved a long neck?
What did Darwin contrast "active Darwinism" with?

context: Popper contrasts his views with the notion of the "<a0_0>hopeful monster<a0_0/>" that has large phenotype mutations and calls it the "<a2_0>hopeful behavioural monster<a2_0/>". After <a1_0>behaviour<a1_0/> has changed radically, <b4_0>small but quick changes of the phenotype<b4_0/> follow to <b5_0>make the organism fitter to its changed goals<b5_0/>. This way it looks as if the phenotype were changing guided by some invisible hand, while it is merely natural selection working in combination with the new behaviour. For example, according to this hypothesis, <b6_0>the eating habits of the giraffe<b6_0/> must have changed before its elongated neck evolved. Popper contrasted this view as "evolution from within" or "<a3_0>active<a3_0/> Darwinism" (the organism actively trying to discover new ways of life and being on a quest for conquering new ecological niches), with the naturalistic "<b7_0>evolution from without<b7_0/>" (which has the picture of a hostile environment only trying to kill the mostly passive organism, or perhaps segregate some of its groups).
